name: Elementary Chinese I
desc: Introduction to Mandarin Chinese, focusing on pronunciation, simple conversation, and basic grammar. Reading and writing Chinese characters are also taught. Writing Chinese characters is required. Four hours per week. Students may not receive credit for both CHIN 101 or CHIN 102 and CHIN 111.

name: Elementary Chinese II
desc: Continued training in listening, speaking, reading, and writing on everyday topics. Writing Chinese characters is required. Four hours per week. Students may not receive credit for both CHIN 101 or CHIN 102 and CHIN 111.

name: Elementary Written Chinese
desc: For students who already understand and speak some Chinese; entry to this course is by placement only. The course focuses on reading and writing. Writing Chinese characters is required. Three hours per week. Students may not receive credit for both CHIN 101 or CHIN 102 and CHIN 111.

name: Introduction to Chinese Civilization
desc: A course designed to introduce students to the Chinese world of past and present. Chinese civilization is explored from a variety of perspectives: political, social, cultural, intellectual, and economic.

name: Intermediate Chinese I
desc: Second-year level of modern standard Chinese. Writing Chinese characters is required. Four hours per week.

name: Intermediate Chinese II
desc: Second-year level of modern standard Chinese. Writing Chinese characters is required. Four hours per week. Students may not receive credit for both CHIN 204 and CHIN 212.

name: Intermediate Written Chinese
desc: For students who already understand and speak some Chinese. The training course focuses on reading and writing. Writing Chinese characters is required. Three hours per week. Students may not receive credit for both CHIN 204 and CHIN 212.

name: Chinese Qin Music
desc: This course offers students an opportunity to learn the aesthetics, culture, and history of qin, and study the music through learning the beginning levels of qin pieces.

name: Introduction to Modern Chinese Culture through Cinema
desc: This course uses select feature and documentary films, supplemented by texts of critical and creative literature, to introduce students to a broad overview of modern China since the mid-19th century, focusing on the major events that have shaped a turbulent course of decline, revolution, and resurgence.

name: Introduction to Chinese Culture through Narrative
desc: This course shows how Chinese historical legends define and transmit the values, concepts, figures of speech, and modes of behavior that constitute Chinese culture.

name: Chinese Language and Society
desc: Chinese language in social, cultural, historical, and political contexts in China. Topics include basic linguistic features, dialects, writing, literacy, and language reform in the era of modernization and globalization.

name: Bandit or Hero: Outlawry in Chinese Literature and Films
desc: This course explores the idea of outlaws as hero in the 16th-century kung-fu novel Outlaws of the Marsh and its influence on modern kung-fu and gangster films.

name: Advanced Chinese I
desc: This course emphasizes the development of conversational skills and vocabulary building with readings on everyday topics. Writing Chinese characters is required. Three hours per week. Students may not receive credit for both CHIN 305 or CHIN 306 and CHIN 313.

name: Advanced Chinese II
desc: This course emphasizes the development of conversational skills and vocabulary building with readings on everyday topics. Writing Chinese characters is required. Three hours per week. Students may not receive credit for both CHIN 305 or CHIN 306 and CHIN 313.

name: Chinese Languages across the Curriculum Recitation
desc: Chinese-language seminar offered in conjunction with selected Chinese content courses taught in English. Students will use the target language (Chinese) to read and discuss weekly topics related to the corresponding content courses. Not intended for native Chinese speakers.

name: Advanced Written Chinese
desc: The third course for Chinese heritage students. Course materials correspond to those in CHIN 305 and CHIN 306. Writing Chinese characters is required. Three hours per week. Students may not receive credit for both CHIN 305 or CHIN 306 and CHIN 313.

name: The Rise of China: A Global and Multidisciplinary Approach
desc: The rise of China has altered the economic and political order of the post-Cold War world. This course examines the historical context and trajectory of China's rise, its internal dynamics, and the challenges it poses to the rest of the world.

name: History as Fiction or Fiction as History? Early Chinese History in Film and Literature
desc: Through analysis of the role movies play in the formation of popular perceptions of the past, this course provides an introduction to the history of the Qin and Han dynasties.

name: Chinese Culture through Calligraphy
desc: For second-language Chinese learners without calligraphy experience.  Includes cultural, historical, and linguistic knowledge about Chinese calligraphy; basic brush writing skills; structure and composition of Chinese characters; how to assemble a calligraphy artwork. Lecture followed by studio session of writing practice. Taught in English and Chinese.

name: Chinese Environmental Literature
desc: Introduces students to Chinese and Taiwanese cultural understandings of human relations to the natural environment. Analyzes classical and modern environmental literature (poetry, essays, fiction, and philosophy) and evaluates how contemporary building practices, governmental policies, and green technologies may be influenced by diverse Chinese philosophical traditions.

name: Chinese Traditional Theater
desc: This course introduces traditional Chinese theater from its earliest development to modern times by examining the interrelation of its elements--music, dance, poetry, and illustration--with performance footage, visual art, and dramatic texts.

name: Illustration and the Animation of Text
desc: This course examines illustration as both a form of literary criticism and a narrative tradition in its own right.

name: Readings in Modern Chinese I
desc: Read authentic texts of modern Chinese, including newspaper articles and writings of literary, cultural, and social interest. Writing Chinese characters is required. Students may not receive credit for both CHIN 407 or CHIN 408 and CHIN 414.

name: Readings in Modern Chinese II
desc: Read authentic texts of modern Chinese, including newspaper articles and writings of literary, cultural, and social interest. Writing Chinese characters is required. Students may not receive credit for both CHIN 407 or CHIN 408 and CHIN 414.

name: Advanced Reading and Composition
desc: Fourth course for heritage students, comparable to CHIN 407 and CHIN 408. Writing Chinese characters is required. Three hours per week. Students may not receive credit for both CHIN 407 or CHIN 408 and CHIN 414.

name: Chinese-English Translation and Interpreting
desc: Instruction and practice in Chinese-to-English translation (written) and interpreting (oral), designed for second-language learners of Chinese. Students work with materials covering many fields.

name: Business Communication in Chinese
desc: The goal of this course is to improve students' overall language proficiency using Chinese for business purposes. They will develop enhanced skills of reading business journalism and case studies and writing business letters or email messages.

name: Narrative Ethics in Modern China
desc: By exploring intersections of the narrative and the normative, this course considers relations between text, ethics, and everyday life in 20th-century China by reading texts on aesthetics.

name: The City in Modern Chinese Literature and Film
desc: This course analyzes historical changes of the city through examining the individual, national, and global identity of Shanghai, Beijing, Taipei, and Hong Kong as reflected in their histories, politics, built environment, ethos, language, and culture.

name: Topics in Chinese Literature and Language
desc: Readings in Chinese literature and language on varying topics. May be taken more than once for credit as topics change.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 12 total credits. 4 total completions.

name: Independent Readings in Chinese
desc: Permission of the department. For the student who wishes to create and pursue an independent project in Chinese under the supervision of a selected instructor. Maximum three credit hours per semester.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 12 total credits. 4 total completions.

name: Introduction to Classical Chinese
desc: Advanced study of Chinese classics.

name: Literary Chinese
desc: Introduction to the classical Chinese language through reading short essays and poems. Instruction focuses on the similarities and differences between classical and modern Chinese in sentence structure and vocabulary.

name: Chinese History in Chinese
desc: This is a fifth-year Chinese course offered as a language course to improve students' language abilities and as a content course surveying Chinese history in Chinese.

name: Ancient Philosophers and Their Modern Reincarnation
desc: Recommended preparation, CHIN 510 or 511. This course examines the reinterpretation and appropriation of ancient Chinese philosophy in contemporary China, on such themes as Confucian ethics and Daoist metaphysics and aesthetics.

name: Chinese Poetry in Translation
desc: Selected topics in Chinese poetry concentrating on one period or one genre.

name: Chinese Prose in Translation
desc: Selected topics in Chinese fiction, historical writing, and prose belles lettres, concentrating on one period or one genre.

name: Contemporary Chinese Urban Culture and Arts
desc: This course analyzes contemporary Chinese urban art, architecture, cinema, and fiction to elucidate dynamics between the built environment and subjectivity. Students analyze how social, economic, and political factors shape environments, and debate whether new urban spaces create social conflict or new civil possibilities.

name: Advanced Topics in Chinese Literature and Language
desc: This is an advanced topics course in Chinese literature and language, culture and society. The instruction is entirely in Chinese with the use of authentic materials. Three hours per week.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 12 total credits. 4 total completions.

name: Chinese Internet Literature
desc: This is a content and language course designed for advanced (native or near-native fluency) undergraduate and graduate students to enhance the four language abilities and cultural literacy. Students will read The Story of Minglan, and analyze the problematic portrayals of traditional women's domestic lives.

name: Writing Chinese (in) America: Advanced Studies of a Foreign Literature from United States Homeland
desc: Encompasses a century of literary writings on the experiences of Chinese in the United States. The select works are written for Chinese communities worldwide, hence writing Chinese in America
Prereqs: while they reflect upon the formation of Chinese American identity, therefore writing Chinese America.""
